item.title: PickPocketing base - 317
item.dc:creator: @johno2 johno2
item.description:
@johno2 wrote:

[quote=“djdoyle1, post:19, topic:275819”][quote author=Primadude link=topic=364350.msg2957880#msg2957880 date=1252961551]

Thanks dude… You have successfully wrecked Project Broken – Im guessing you dont know how to code?
1.
} for every {
2.
Learn how to include a class in a piece of code.

Come back when you have ^^

There aren’t any unclosed braces in this tutorial. Either you are retarded, and added your own extra braces, or you just cannot learn from this and/or copy and paste.
[/quote]

OK no I didnt add my own “Braces” - I dont have braces LEARN TO TYPE![/quote]

Yeh dude, before you start slagging off other peoples work, how about you check what you added, remove/add the bracket and then apologize… Or do you need spoon feeding that as well?

Read full topic

item.title: PickPocketing base - 317
item.dc:creator: @primadude Primadude
item.description:
@primadude wrote:

[quote=“djdoyle1, post:19, topic:275819”][quote author=Primadude link=topic=364350.msg2957880#msg2957880 date=1252961551]

Thanks dude… You have successfully wrecked Project Broken – Im guessing you dont know how to code?
1.
} for every {
2.
Learn how to include a class in a piece of code.

Come back when you have ^^

There aren’t any unclosed braces in this tutorial. Either you are retarded, and added your own extra braces, or you just cannot learn from this and/or copy and paste.
[/quote]

OK no I didnt add my own “Braces” - I dont have braces LEARN TO TYPE![/quote]

Most people call them brackets, but they’re called braces.

Edit: Read here:

http://java.sun.com/docs/books/tutorial/java/nutsandbolts/expressions.html

In the blocks part.

Also:

http://www.leepoint.net/notes-java/flow/if/30if-braces.html

Read full topic

item.description:
@Joea wrote:

client.java:33199: class, interface, or enum expected
if (thievingType > 0 && thiefNPC) {
^
client.java:33202: class, interface, or enum expected
thief.ThiefStart(this);
^
client.java:33203: class, interface, or enum expected
}
^
client.java:33207: class, interface, or enum expected
}
^
client.java:33210: class, interface, or enum expected
thief.ThiefFinish(this);
^
client.java:33211: class, interface, or enum expected
}→
^
6 errors
Finished!
Press any key to continue . . .

I get this please help

^ client.java:165: illegal start of expression public long thiefTimer; ^ client.java:166: illegal start of expression public int thiefDelay; ^ client.java:167: illegal start of expression public int thievingType; ^ client.java:168: illegal start of expression public boolean thiefNPC; ^ client.java:169: illegal start of expression public int ThiefNPC; ^ client.java:15462: illegal start of type if (thievingType > 0 && thiefNPC) { ^ client.java:15462: <identifier> expected if (thievingType > 0 && thiefNPC) { ^ client.java:15462: ';' expected if (thievingType > 0 && thiefNPC) { ^ client.java:15462: illegal start of type if (thievingType > 0 && thiefNPC) { ^ client.java:15462: ';' expected if (thievingType > 0 && thiefNPC) { ^ client.java:15468: illegal start of type if (thiefDelay > 0) { ^ client.java:15468: <identifier> expected if (thiefDelay > 0) { ^ client.java:15468: ';' expected if (thiefDelay > 0) { ^ client.java:15468: illegal start of type if (thiefDelay > 0) { ^ client.java:15468: <identifier> expected if (thiefDelay > 0) { ^ client.java:15468: ';' expected if (thiefDelay > 0) { ^ client.java:15469: illegal start of type thiefDelay--; ^ client.java:15469: <identifier> expected thiefDelay--; ^ client.java:15469: ';' expected thiefDelay--; ^ client.java:15471: illegal start of type if (thiefDelay == 1) { ^ client.java:15471: <identifier> expected if (thiefDelay == 1) { ^ client.java:15471: ';' expected if (thiefDelay == 1) { ^ client.java:15471: illegal start of type if (thiefDelay == 1) { ^ client.java:15471: <identifier> expected if (thiefDelay == 1) { ^ client.java:15471: ';' expected if (thiefDelay == 1) { ^ 32 errors Finished!

item.title: PickPocketing base - 317

item.description:
@primadude wrote:

Taharok:

Of course I’ll approve of this one. However, you really should be commenting your code more. It helps remind you of things you may forget in the future and helps others learn what each piece of code does.

I will work on that now. Thanks for the heads up.

Edit: I have updated the post to explain the codes a lot more, and in more depth :).
